theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on accumulation of somatic mutations causing cellular and organ dysfunction leading to aging.
Emphasizes tissue-specific mutation accumulation and DNA repair defects in somatic cells driving aging.
Highlights somatic mutation accumulation causing decline in cellular and organ function and age-related diseases.
Links somatic mutation rates inversely with lifespan and proposes a mutation burden threshold for aging.
Describes universal senescence caused by accumulation of deleterious mutations in biological machinery.
Focuses on accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations due to declining natural selection with age.
Describes accumulation of late-onset deleterious mutations escaping selection due to weakened force of natural selection with age.
Posits age-dependent accumulation of deleterious mutations with effects manifesting late in life causing senescence.
Emphasizes relaxed selection at old age allowing accumulation of late-acting deleterious alleles.
Models accumulation of deleterious mutations expressed after reproduction causing aging.
Focuses on declining selection with age allowing late-life deleterious mutations to accumulate.
Explains aging as accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations reaching a threshold causing death.
Describes accumulation of late-acting mutations causing senescence and catastrophic senescence in semelparous species.
Proposes age-specific accumulation of deleterious mutations causing senescence and increased genetic effects with age.
Focuses on age-specific deleterious mutations accumulating due to weaker selection at older ages.
Posits accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations increasing genetic variance and senescence.
Describes accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations due to declining force of natural selection with age.
Integrates mutation accumulation with evolutionary theories including antagonistic pleiotropy and disposable soma focusing on life-history trade-offs.
Links extrinsic mortality and evolutionary trade-offs to mutation accumulation shaping longevity.
Focuses on extrinsic mortality and condition-dependent mortality shaping functional senescence and lifespan evolution.
Drift barrier theory linking population size, mutation effects, and life-history parameters to limits on lifespan evolution.
Emphasizes population size effects on mutation accumulation and genome evolution influencing life history and aging.
Describes mutation-selection-drift balance shaping genetic correlations and evolutionary trajectories relevant to aging.
Adaptive geometry model of age-dependent mutation effects integrating mutation accumulation with age-structured adaptation.
